Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research in Interactive Virtual Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site renewal is to engage 10 undergraduate students per summer at the University of Southern California's Institute for Creative Technologies, a unique multidisciplinary research community that combines leading academic researchers in computer science, psychology, communications, cinematic arts, and medicine. Participants will be immersed in collaborative research teams focused on the institute's core theme of interactive virtual experiences, with specific projects in areas such as virtual reality, narrative, virtual humans, natural language dialogue, and graphics. These activities will be combined with weekly interactive seminars for training in best research practices, mentorship support, and peer feedback.

The techniques and technologies developed by the researchers drive the creation of compelling synthetic environments and characters with immediate relevance to a broad range of application domains including training, education, rehabilitation, and medicine. The undergraduate students will become engaged in summer experiences that emphasize interdisciplinary research, with the goals of broadening participation from underrepresented populations in computing and exposing undergraduate students to opportunities in science and engineering graduate programs. This effort has the potential to prepare undergraduates to perform independent research, thereby increasing enrollment and retention in computing doctoral programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported summer undergraduate research experiences at the USC Institute for Creative Technologies, a unique multidisciplinary research community that combines leading academic researchers in computer science, psychology, communications, cinematic arts, and medicine with the creative talents of Hollywood and the video game industry. Participants were immersed in collaborative research teams focused on the institute's core theme of interactive virtual experiences. REU student research projects have advanced the state-of-the-art in virtual reality, graphics, human-computer interaction, artificial intelligence, and natural language understanding. These techniques and technologies drive the creation of compelling synthetic environments and virtual characters with relevance to a broad range of applications including training, education, rehabilitation, medicine, and entertainment. The research supported under this award has resulted in 20 published papers with undergraduate co-authors. 


The broader impact of this project lies in the engagement of undergraduate students in summer experiences that emphasize interdisciplinary research, with the goals of broadening participation from underrepresented groups and exposing undergraduate students to opportunities in computing graduate programs. Research activities were supplemented by weekly interactive seminars for professional development and annual symposia organized in cooperation with other REU sites. Of the 47 undergraduates that have been supported under this award, 60% came from academic institutions where research programs in STEM are limited, 60% were female or non-binary, and 30% identified as members of other historically marginalized groups that are underrepresented in STEM-related fields. Many alumni of this program have subsequently enrolled in computing graduate programs after completing their undergraduate degrees.
